Achilles spends eight books (chapters) of The Iliad in his tent with Patroclus because he refuses to fight. I’m not Homer, I’m not Madeline Miller. I’m Saeed Jones and I’m here to remind you that Achilles and Patroclus were FUCKING. That tent smelled like sweat, moans and choices.
Achilles’ rant stresses Phoenix out so much homeboy literally bursts into tears!!! Achilles was putting them THROUGH IT, you hear me? A legendary stunt queen.
“Cowards and heroes get the same rewards. Death still comes.” Achilles, PLEASE!!!! 😭😭😭😭

The thing about Achilles is that when the Trojan War is about to start, he’s a teenager who KNOWS his he will die very soon. His dignity is all he has. His dignity and whatever fleeting love he was able to build with Patroclus. I didn’t understand those stakes until Madeline Miller’s novel. 😭

When Odysseus and some of the other Greeks show up at their tent, Achilles and Patroclus basically host a dinner party for them. 😩😭 They’re so cute. I mean, I guess it was more of a barbecue. But still!
Then my work here is done.

I’ve made it to Book 7 of Emily Wilson’s translation of THE ILIAD. And let me tell you something, niggas are dying left and right, front back and center! SHIT!!! Sometimes Homer doesn’t even introduce a character until *after* he’s died!!! It’s wild. WHEW!

In high school, I was so confused by several characters in The Iliad having the same name. Like, there are Ajaxes all over the place. But then, in college, I had sex with three or four Ryans in a row, quickly followed by two Roberts. And I was like “oh, I get it now.”
I love her books. Circe is incredible too. I believe her next book is about Persephone!!!

Natalie Haynes (in her excellent podcast) says that The Illiad shows multiple ways of what it means to be "a man," with Hector being a good example.

Nestor, if you don’t get your old ass back to the ship! You’re stressing me out! This is the Trojan War, not the US Senate! Go sit down somewhere.

Diomedes is BAAAAD motherfucker. Every time he shows up, I get nervous. He’s so deadly. Zeus sends a lightning bolt to crash right in front of Diomedes’ chariot to keep him from killing Nestor!!!! I’m shook.
The disdain with which Homer calls Ares, the god of war, “the human killer”… WHEW!!!
I’ve only noticed it this go-around. But once you clock it, bloody nipples are everywhere you turn in the poem.

In addition to her excellent skills as a translator, Emily Wilson wrote an extensive introduction to The Iliad in which she parses ideas about mortality, gender, polytheism, etc etc etc and I found that to be really affecting. I don’t think I’ve gotten choked up reading an introduction before.
It’s so good!!!
“And then they laid down and took the gift of sleep.” THE ILIAD is so good.
A MAN!!!
It’s all so much!!!!
And like, no disrespect to Andromache, but I just KNOW Hector was fine as frog hair and slinging heavy meat. Every time Homer describes Hector’s shiny helmet, I’m like “😏 Oh, I BET it was shiny.”

Hector’s son was just an infant but people of Troy nicknamed him something that meant “the lord of the city” because they all knew that his dad was THEE WARRIOR keeping them safe. I find that so touching.

The story of Hector and Andromache is so sad. It didn’t register with me in school because I was too distracted by my teacher’s insistence that Achilles and Patroclus were “just friends.” But Hector and Andromache seem to KNOW that they are doomed. Everything they fear comes true. But even worse.
Everyday was Octoberfest. I love it.
And look, Homer only *mentions* nipples when they’re being pierced by spears and swords! Dude had a kink.

Which leads me to wonder… do you actually believe what you say you believe in OR is it really about how your belief makes you FEEL? Because a reliance on smugness, I think, implies that you’re enthralled more so by the feeling than the belief itself.

Like, if you deeply cared about something you believed in, wouldn’t you take care to discuss it in a way that would be persuasive to others? Wouldn’t you want to win them over and embrace them? But then, so often, smugness HAPPENS.

Okay, so the gist I’m getting is “I’d rather DIE than do THAT.” Arguably, “oh hell no” IE “I’d rather die and go to hell rather than do THAT” is more rhetorically effective and logically consistent than “oh heaven’s no” but death is still death. Ugh, I love words so much. *sips more wine*

But… *takes another sip of wine* *looks off into the distance* If you think about it, there’s still a bit of mystery to the phrase “OH HELL NO.” Like, I get the intention of that declaration but where did it come from? How does “oh absolutely not, NOPE” become “oh hell no”?

I curse so much that it literally never  occurred to me that it’s obviously a church mother’s way of saying “OH HELL NAW.” Such elegance. I’m glad I asked. It’s fun to learn about the turns of phrase that raised us so well we take them for granted.
